Notes: No changes   Schools open with mask wearing still in place and other distancing measures   http://web.archive.org/web/20220219143447/https://www.gov.bm/covid-19-guidance-schools-childcare-facilities

From 12:00 pm on Friday February 4 2022:      SafeKey is no longer mandatory for restaurants, members' clubs, bars, gyms and island boats. They are only required for large group events that require a group exemption.      Restaurant table sizes are limited to 10      Employees of these establishments are not required to have a SafeKey in order to go to work as all employees are required to remain masked at all times.  Effective April 1 2022, Safekeys will no longer be issued.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220219143014/https://www.gov.bm/safekey

Gatherings are restricted to groups of no more than 100 people. Exemptions will be subject to the Standard Large Group Conditions, including a limit of 50% capacity at any venue to enter the event    http://web.archive.org/web/20220206185126/https://www.gov.bm/covid-19-guidance-events-and-gatherings
Gatherings are restricted to groups of no more than 100 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220206185126/https://www.gov.bm/covid-19-guidance-events-and-gatherings

No changes:  All visitors arriving by air or sea to Bermuda must be fully vaccinated except for persons younger than 18 years and working crew.  Residents do not have a vaccination requirement.  Upon arrival to Bermuda, vaccinated travellers are required to get an arrival PCR test and a Day 4 antigen test  Unvaccinated travellers are required to get an arrival PCR test and a Day 10 antigen test (arrival day=Day 0) and must quarantine on arrival until their day 10 negative test result is received    http://web.archive.org/web/20220217170359/https://www.gov.bm/applying-bermuda-travel-authorisation

On 31 January 2022, elementary and secondary schools in the province of New Brunswick (NB) move from online to in-class learning. Elementary and secondary schools are open for in-class learning throughout Canada EXCEPT Igloolik, Nunavut Territory where all levels are closed including the Igloolik Community Learning Centre campus of Nunavut Arctic College. No jurisdiction has implemented a vaccine or testing mandate for students. Many post-secondary institutions throughout Canada are offering most classes online. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. E.g., âUniversities in Ontario have been told by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities that there are no restrictions on in-person instructionâ. However, at the University of NB: âFollowing the guidance of Public Health and to assist our province in managing the impacts of the current outbreak â¦ Only courses that must be delivered in-person to meet course outcomes will resume in-person classes on Monday, Jan. 24. All other courses will continue to be offered remotely and will transition to in-person instruction on Monday, Feb. 7.â In other words, post-secondary instruction in NB is online âfollowingâ provincial government public health guidance. See governments of NB, University of NB and Globe and Mail newspaper websites archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131170000/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/information/nunavuts-path  https://web.archive.org/web/20220121134059/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-universities-to-stick-to-online-classes-for-now-to-slow-spread-of/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220113203046/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/news/news_release.2022.01.0019.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220113210148/https://www.unb.ca/coronavirus/community-updates/jan-13-22.html

On 7 February 2022, elementary and secondary schools are open for in-class learning throughout Canada EXCEPT in Igloolik, Nunavut Territory where all levels are closed including the Igloolik Community Learning Centre campus of Nunavut Arctic College. . No jurisdiction has implemented a vaccine or testing mandate for students. Many post-secondary institutions throughout Canada are offering most classes online or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. E.g., âUniversities in Ontario have been told by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities that there are no restrictions on in-person instructionâ. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âWe have been working very closely with Public Health since the beginning of the pandemic and all major decisions have been informed by its input and general guidanceâ¦layered protection â¦ approach Memorial has taken with the vaccine mandate, mandatory three-ply masks, asymptomatic rapid testing, wastewater testing, density requirements, cleaning and hygiene and ventilation standards for classrooms and labs.â The post-secondary vaccine mandate is a decision made by MUN âworking very closely with Public Health â¦informed by its input and general guidanceâ. See government of Nunavut, MUN and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211144521/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/information/nunavuts-path  https://web.archive.org/web/20220121134059/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-universities-to-stick-to-online-classes-for-now-to-slow-spread-of/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129121757/https://gazette.mun.ca/campus-and-community/return-to-campus-update/

On 7 february 2022, non-essential businesses and services remain closed in Igloolik, Nunavut Territory since 25 Jan. In the rest of Canada, businesses are open with different levels of restrictions in different provinces and territories. Many jurisdictions restrict access to some non-essential businesses to fully vaccinated customers (or require proof of a recent negative test). See Globe and Mail newspaper and government of Nunavvut website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206121540/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-mandatory-vaccination-canada-province-territory-policies-guide/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131170000/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/information/nunavuts-path

In the rest of Canada, businesses are open with different levels of restrictions in different provinces and territories. Some jurisdictions restrict access to some non-essential businesses to fully vaccinated customers (or require proof of a recent negative test). On 7 February 2022, in most of Canada organized public events such as concerts and sports matches are restricted to limited capacity for vaccinated persons. However, the Province of Alberta provides an opt-out: âIndoor facilities that do not implement the Restrictions Exemption Program [vaccination/test mandate] must follow these restrictions: Limit capacity to 1/3 fire code occupancy. Require attendees to be with household members only, or 2 close contacts if they live alone.â In Igloolik, Nunavut Territory, non-emergency events are banned for all persons, regardless of vaccination status. âIndoor gatherings, halls, conference spaces, government and Inuit organization facilities Maximum amount of people 0 (+5 for emergencies)â. In sum, 2T fits both vaccinated and unvaccinated. See Globe and Mail newspaper and Alberta and Nunavut government websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131170000/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/information/nunavuts-path  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206121540/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-mandatory-vaccination-canada-province-territory-policies-guide/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207011529/https://www.alberta.ca/covid-19-public-health-actions.aspx

On 11 February 2022, in most of Canada organized public events such as concerts and sports matches are restricted to vaccinated persons, and even then with limited capacity in some jurisdictions. However, âAlberta Premier â¦ said his province would eliminate its [vaccine] passport program at midnight on Tuesday [8 Feb.) â¦ [and] said âNow is the time to begin learning to live with COVID-19â¦None of that has to do anything with a few trucks parked at the Coutts border crossing.â Alberta recorded 1,623 people with COVID-19 in hospital as of Feb. 7, compared to 1,570 on Jan. 27, when [Premier] said the government would back off restrictions when hospital admissions were on a sustained downward trend.â In Igloolik, Nunavut Territory, non-emergency events are banned for all persons, regardless of vaccination status. âIndoor gatherings, halls, conference spaces, government and Inuit organization facilities Maximum amount of people 0 (+5 for emergencies)â. In sum, 2T fits both vaccinated and unvaccinated. See Globe and Mail newspaper and Nunavut government websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211144521/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/information/nunavuts-path  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210154614/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-saskatchewan-premier-scott-moe-brings-provinces-vaccine-passport-mask/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206121540/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-mandatory-vaccination-canada-province-territory-policies-guide/

See Government of Canada website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220211145015/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/domestic-travel  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154602/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/provinces

On 7 February 2022, Canada remains open to entry by non-citizens, but only those who meet the following requirements: âyou can enter Canada if you qualify as a fully vaccinated traveller or youâre coming for a non-optional purpose â¦ Fully vaccinated travellers must also meet all other entry criteria, including: submitting all required COVID-19 information into ArriveCAN prior to travel â¦being asymptomatic upon arrival; having a paper or digital copy of your proof of vaccination â¦; and having a suitable quarantine plan, in case it is required. Within 72 hours before your arrival to Canada or prior to scheduled departure of flight to Canada: Take a pre-entry COVID-19 molecular test (Antigen tests are not accepted for entry) or have proof of a positive test result received in the previous 14-180 daysâ¦After entry (coming from any country other than the U.S. in the past 14 days) Quarantine until receipt of your negative arrival test. Answer compliance verification calls from the Government of Canada â¦If you test positive or develop symptoms, you are required to isolate for 10 days from the time the test result is received, or the start of symptoms. You also need to contact the Public Health Agency of Canadaâ. In sum, the Canadian border is closed to all unvaccinated, non-essential foreign visitors. The Canadian border is open to fully vaccinated foreign visitors. Fully vaccinated Americans are subject to screening requirements. Fully vaccinated non-Americans are subject to quarantine until they receive a negative covid test administered on arrival. Some truck drivers and their supporters continue blockades as a protest against the national governmentâs decision to effectively amend the definition of non-optional or essential worker to exclude less-than-fully-vaccinated foreign truck drivers from 15 January 2022. Unvaccinated Canadian truck drivers re-entering Canada from the USA will need to meet testing and quarantine requirements. See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116121106/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2022/01/requirements-for-truckers-entering-canada-in-effect-as-of-january-15-2022.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207012422/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ottawa-and-provincial-capitals-on-alert-as-convoy-protests-ramp-up/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206220154/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/fully-vaccinated-travellers-entering-canada-covid-19.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206220039/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/visitors-workers-students

Within 72 hours before your arrival to Canada or prior to scheduled departure of flight to Canada: Take a pre-entry COVID-19 molecular test (Antigen tests are not accepted for entry) or have proof of a positive test result received in the previous 14-180 daysâ¦After entry (coming from any country other than the U.S. in the past 14 days) Quarantine until receipt of your negative arrival test. On 7 February 2022, the government of Canada continues the program: âThe Canada Worker Lockdown Benefit [CWLB] provides $300 a week to eligible workers who are unable to work due to a temporary local lockdown anytime between October 24, 2021 and May 7, 2022. The benefit is only available when a COVID-19 lockdown order is designated for your region.â All Canadians are eligible to receive this national government support when they live in a province, territory or regional health district that meets the definition of being in âlockdownâ. The âCanada Recovery Sickness Benefit [CRSB], a $450-a-week federal subsidy for people who are ill or who need to isolate because of COVID-19 â¦uptake of the program has been weak. Since its introduction in the fall of 2020 there have only been about 820,000 applicants. Canadaâs initial pandemic subsidy for individuals, the Canada Emergency Recovery Benefit (better known as CERB), had about 8.9 million before it ended.â Both CWLB and CRSB benefit levels are less than 50% of pre-crisis average earnings of just over C$1,000/week. (Average weekly earnings excluding overtime increased almost 7% from 2019 to 2020 in part thanks to the reduction in employment in low-wage sectors such as hospitality that were hit harder by the covid crisis.) See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220127154033/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220203183952/https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/cv.action?pid=1410020401  https://web.archive.org/web/20220203184154/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/article-paid-sick-days-covid-leave-essential-workers/

On 11 February 2022, the government of Canada continues the program: âThe Canada Worker Lockdown Benefit â¦ provides income support of $300 per week to workers whose employment is affected as a result of a public health lockdown and who are either unable to work or have lost 50 per cent or more of their income due to such restrictions. The regulatory changes announced on December 22, 2021, temporarily expanded the definition of a public health lockdown order to also include those involving capacity restrictions of 50 per cent or more. The benefit is available from October 24, 2021, to May 7, 2022. The government has implemented other measures â¦Extending the Canada Recovery Caregiving Benefit and the Canada Recovery Sickness Benefit until May 7, 2022â. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210214328/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2022/02/government-extends-expanded-access-to-local-lockdown-program-and-worker-lockdown-benefit.html

On 7 feb. 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow and other rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in many parts of Canada, the caseload wave frustrated efforts to achieve testing aspirations. Many jurisdictions are targeting testing â e.g., the Province of Ontario Chief Medical Officer âsaid â¦ âPCR testing. Weâre limiting it specifically to those high-risk populations and settingsâ...In the absence of better tracking and accuracy of rapid tests, other metrics can help monitor the spread of COVID-19, including hospital and ICU admissions, COVID-19 levels in wastewater, the percentage of positive tests â¦ antibodies in random samples of blood tests â¦member of the provinceâs science advisory table â¦ said.â See Government of Canada and toronto Star newspaper websites, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220206221032/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220203190627/https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2022/02/02/ontario-seeks-to-expand-use-of-rapid-tests-in-shifting-pandemic-strategy.html

On 11 feb. 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow and other rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in many parts of Canada, the caseload wave frustrated efforts to achieve testing aspirations. Many jurisdictions are targeting testing â e.g., in Canadaâs most populous province, Ontario: âThe governmentâs rapid-test announcement was also marred by confusion over how the tests should be used. [Health Minister] said Ontarians could use the tests as an âadditional toolâ to âconfidently do the things they love, like visiting family, or dining out at their favourite local restaurant.â But a slide deck distributed to reporters outlining the plans â¦ says the tests are intended for those with symptoms and âgenerally not recommendedâ for use by asymptomatic people with no known exposure before a social event. Asked about the contradiction, [Health Minister] responded that the tests should only be used before visiting vulnerable or immunocompromised people â¦ government previously faced criticism for cutting off access to its lab-confirmed polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests, reserving them for people at highest risk, such as long-term care residents and health workers, as the Omicron wave threatened to overwhelm the system. It has also faced flak for not making rapid tests more widely available. While it has distributed millions through schools, its move to hand them out at liquor stores in December resulted in long lines and shortages.â See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220210153117/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210152700/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-free-rapid-tests-ontario-covid-19-pharmacies-grocery-stores/

On 7 feb. 2022, government of Canada advises that when individuals âtest positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.â Most provinces and territories intend to follow this practice, if conditions and resources permit. However, tracing capacity is not sufficient in many jurisdictions to deal with a surge in cases. E.g., in the province of British Columbia (BC): âAt this stage in the pandemic, close contacts are not required to self-isolate or take any special measures. Therefore, contact tracing is of limited value except for high-priority settings. Public Health will follow up with COVID-19 close contacts in â¦High priority settingsâ. See Governments of Canada and BC websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206221032/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220203191914/http://www.bccdc.ca/health-info/diseases-conditions/covid-19/self-isolation/close-contacts

It's a key public health measure.â Most provinces and territories intend to follow this practice, if conditions and resources permit. However, tracing capacity is not sufficient in many jurisdictions to deal with a surge in cases. E.g., in Canadaâs most populous province, Ontario: âOmicron variant cases spiked in December and January, overwhelming health resources to the point that the province restricted access to tests, scaled back contact tracing effortsâ. See Government of Canada and and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210153117/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211135552/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reviewing-all-covid-19-measures-including-masks-and-vaccine/

On 7 feb. 2022, all provinces and territories continue to require masks in indoor public spaces consistent with Government of Canada advice about âthe importance of layering protections to reduce infection and spread of the virusâ¦such as properly wearing a well-fitted and well-constructed face maskâ. Even in the province of Saskatchewan, where there are no gathering limits and the âpremier announced the end of â¦ proof of vaccination policy in the not-too-distant future", it remains the case that âmasks are mandatory in indoor public spacesâ. See Government of Canada, CBC and Globe and Mail news, and McCarthy Law websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205203831/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206121540/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-mandatory-vaccination-canada-province-territory-policies-guide/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220127161451/https://www.mccarthy.ca/en/insights/articles/covid-19-recovery-and-re-opening-tracker  https://web.archive.org/web/20220203154234/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/scott-moe-vaccination-covid-19-not-reducing-transmission-1.6332710

On 11 feb. 2022, all provinces and territories continue to require masks in indoor public spaces consistent with Government of Canada advice about âthe importance of layering protections to reduce infection and spread of the virusâ¦such as properly wearing a well-fitted and well-constructed face maskâ. Even in Saskatchewan, where âpremier said it was now time to move on from a policy under which the benefits no longer outweigh the costâ¦[and] recently stated that "vaccination does not keep you from contracting COVID-19" [and] the province stopped providing daily COVID-19 updatesâ, there are âindoor mask mandates [until] the end of the monthâ. Albertaâs mask mandate will be relaxed on 14 Feb. See Government of Canada, CTV, CBC and Globe and Mail news, and McCarthy Law websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210185611/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160945/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/not-in-the-clear-yet-most-provinces-stick-with-gradual-covid-19-reopening-plans-1.5774910  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206121540/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-mandatory-vaccination-canada-province-territory-policies-guide/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220127161451/https://www.mccarthy.ca/en/insights/articles/covid-19-recovery-and-re-opening-tracker  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210162130/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/covid-19-update-feb-8-2022-1.6343563

On 6 feb. 2022 4:42PM, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 31,999,377 Canadians (84% of the total national population and 88% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 5+) have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen, or AstraZeneca (no longer recommended except in limited circumstances).30,344,423 Canadians (79% of total pop. and 83.5% of vax-eligible aged 5+) have received two doses. All provinces and territories are making vaccinations available to residents aged 5 and up. Vaccinations for those aged 5-11 started in late November 2021. Provinces and territories are also delivering third doses to long-term care residents, immune-compromised patients, indigenous community residents, senior citizens and recipients of two earlier AZ doses based on national government guidance. The Government-of-Canada-recommended age for third doses has been lowered to those aged 50 and up and to age 18+ where local circumstances warrant. 16,254,970 third doses have been administered accounting for 42% of the national population. Some provinces have started delivering fourth doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential work trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different provinces, vaccinations took place at work, and both provinces count the vaccinations.) âFree vaccines will be available to everyone in Canada.â See government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205194529/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/vaccines.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205192553/https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/vaccination-coverage/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207121217/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine-booster-eligibility-by-province-and-territory-in-canada  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107190826/https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/guidance-booster-covid-19-vaccine-doses/summary.pdf

On 11 feb. 2022 10:20AM, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 32,112,300 Canadians (84% of the total national population and 88% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 5+) have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen, or AstraZeneca (no longer recommended except in limited circumstances). 30,520,007 Canadians (just under 80% of total pop. and 84% of vax-eligible aged 5+) have received two doses. All provinces and territories are making vaccinations available to residents aged 5 and up. Vaccinations for those aged 5-11 started in late November 2021. Provinces and territories are also delivering third doses to long-term care residents, immune-compromised patients, indigenous community residents, senior citizens and recipients of two earlier AZ doses based on national government guidance. The Government-of-Canada-recommended age for third doses has been lowered to those aged 50 and up and to age 18+ where local circumstances warrant. 16,691,198 third doses have been administered accounting for 43% of the national population. Some provinces have started delivering fourth doses and third doses to those aged 12-17. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential work trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different provinces, vaccinations took place at work, and both provinces count the vaccinations.) âFree vaccines will be available to everyone in Canada.â See government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210190338/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/vaccines.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220210191144/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine-booster-eligibility-by-province-and-territory-in-canada  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107190826/https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/guidance-booster-covid-19-vaccine-doses/summary.pdf

On 7 Feb. 2022, Nunavut Territory has the strictest policy in Canada with an order regardless of vaccination status: âLong term care facilities, continuing care â¦ Closed to visitors, residents restricted to facilities and groundsâ in Igloolik since 25 Jan. Many jurisdictions prohibit unvaccinated visitors and staff. At least one jurisdiction (Yukon Territory) has narrow restrictions on visitors and no policy restricting unvaccinated visitors. In sum, extensive protections restrict visitors regardless of vaccination status in some parts of Canada and extensive protections prohibit unvaccinated visitors in most, but not all, of Canada. See governments of Nunavut, Yukon, Newfoundland and Labrador, Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:    https://web.archive.org/web/20220131170000/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/information/nunavuts-path  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206121540/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-mandatory-vaccination-canada-province-territory-policies-guide/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117121246/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/vaccination-record/citizens/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207120211/https://yukon.ca/en/health-and-wellness/covid-19-information/long-term-care-visitation-guidelines-covid-19
